      79             : // In theory, on Windows, this is a valid process ID, but in practice they are
      80             : // currently divisible by four. Process IDs share the kernel handle allocation
      81             : // code and they are guaranteed to be divisible by four.

      83             : // property, however even if that were to change, it seems safe to rely on this
      84             : // particular value never being used.

     542             : 
     543             : /**
     544             :  * An endpoint represents one end of a partially initialized IPDL channel. To
     545             :  * set up a new top-level protocol:
     546             :  *
     547             :  * Endpoint<PFooParent> parentEp;
     548             :  * Endpoint<PFooChild> childEp;
     549             :  * nsresult rv;
     550             :  * rv = PFoo::CreateEndpoints(parentPid, childPid, &parentEp, &childEp);
     551             :  *
     552             :  * You're required to pass in parentPid and childPid, which are the pids of the
     553             :  * processes in which the parent and child endpoints will be used.
     554             :  *
     555             :  * Endpoints can be passed in IPDL messages or sent to other threads using
     556             :  * PostTask. Once an Endpoint has arrived at its destination process and thread,
     557             :  * you need to create the top-level actor and bind it to the endpoint:
     558             :  *
     559             :  * FooParent* parent = new FooParent();
     560             :  * bool rv1 = parentEp.Bind(parent, processActor);
     561             :  * bool rv2 = parent->SendBar(...);
     562             :  *
     563             :  * (See Bind below for an explanation of processActor.) Once the actor is bound
     564             :  * to the endpoint, it can send and receive messages.
     565             :  */
     566             : template<class PFooSide>

     708        1365 : class ManagedContainer : public nsTHashtable<nsPtrHashKey<Protocol>>

     710             :   typedef nsTHashtable<nsPtrHashKey<Protocol>> BaseClass;
     711             : 
     712             : public:
     713             :   // Having the core logic work on void pointers, rather than typed pointers,
     714             :   // means that we can have one instance of this code out-of-line, rather
     715             :   // than several hundred instances of this code out-of-lined.  (Those
     716             :   // repeated instances don't necessarily get folded together by the linker
     717             :   // because they contain member offsets and such that differ between the
     718             :   // functions.)  We do have to pay for it with some eye-bleedingly bad casts,
     719             :   // though.
     720             :   void ToArray(nsTArray<Protocol*>& aArray) const {
     721         465 :     ::mozilla::ipc::TableToArray(*reinterpret_cast<const nsTHashtable<nsPtrHashKey<void>>*>

     723         465 :                                  reinterpret_cast<nsTArray<void*>&>(aArray));
